abstract.p: Public Health Research Institute Dir David S Perlin letter on Feb 27 article criticizes FBI for dallying in sub-typing anthrax strain four months after letter incidents occurred

block.p: Re ''Labs Are Sent Subpoenas for Samples of Anthrax'' (news article, Feb. 27):
Re ''Labs Are Sent Subpoenas for Samples of Anthrax'' (news article, Feb. 27):

It is indeed troubling that four months after identifying the outbreak strain of anthrax as the Ames strain, the F.B.I. is just getting around to issuing subpoenas for samples from labs around the country.

Several months ago, the genome sequence for Bacillus anthracis was decoded, and it was announced that new genetic markers had been identified that were being used to sub-type the Ames strain. Subtleties in the genomic sequences are relatively easy to determine by DNA sequencing. So why is it taking so long to sub-type the Ames strains from all government and academic labs?

The handling of the anthrax outbreak has left a nervous public skeptical about the effectiveness of government agencies. If the F.B.I. and their consultants are uncertain about the best approach, then let other specialized academic labs bring molecular typing expertise to the table.
DAVID S. PERLIN Scientific Director Public Health Research Institute New York, Feb. 28, 2002
